question.text: Which of the following will have the same ploidy level?

options.text: Primary spermatocyte, primary oocyte, and second polar body
Oogonia, primary oocyte, and first polar body
Second polar body, spermatids, and primary spermatocyte
First polar body, secondary oocyte, and spermatozoa

solution.text:
In human females, during oogenesis, the diploid structure with 46 chromosomes 44+XX is oogonium, which divides mitotically and gives rise to the primary oocyte (2n). Secondary oocyte, first and second polar body and ovum are produced as a result of meiotic division, and hence, they are haploid in nature.

In human males, during spermatogenesis, in the diploid structure with 46 chromosomes, 44+XY is spermatogonium, which grows in size and volume and produces to the primary spermatocyte (2n). Secondary spermatocyte, spermatids and spermatozoa are produced as a result of meiotic division and spermiogenesis; hence, they are haploid in nature.
